G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and the incident occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and the incident occurred in Newton, Massachusetts.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3).proposition: Venue is proper in this District under Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3) and G.L. c. 223, § 8, because the wrongful acts alleged occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this District under Mass. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(3) and G.L. c. 223, § 8, because the wrongful acts alleged occurred within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

Newton City Ordinance, Chapter 3, \u00a7.proposition: Posted signs throughout the park state clearly that all dogs must be kept on a leash at all times, pursuant to Newton City Ordinance, Chapter 3, § 3‑12, and G.L. c. 140, § 173, which authorize municipalities to regulate the restraint of dogs.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 173.proposition: Posted signs throughout the park state clearly that all dogs must be kept on a leash at all times, pursuant to Newton City Ordinance, Chapter 3, § 3‑12, and G.L. c. 140, § 173, which authorize municipalities to regulate the restraint of dogs.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every individual owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not articulate any general Massachusetts rule that every individual owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm. Instead, it assumes for purposes of argument that a duty may exist and resolves the negligence claims solely on the element of causation, explicitly noting it need not decide whether the defendant owed a duty. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the broad duty proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

Anderson v. Dimond, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 34.raw_text: Anderson v. Dimond, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 343 (2020)
Anderson v. Dimond, 97 Mass. App. Ct. 34.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every individual owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155\u2013157.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of care to ensure that his dog was on a leash and under his control, consistent with G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–157, § 173, and Newton City Ordinances regulating dogs in public areas.

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violation of a safety statute or ordinance designed to protect the public constitutes evidence of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of violating a safety statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) on civil negligence liability. The court reiterates the Massachusetts rule that statutory violation is not negligence per se but is "some evidence" of negligence as to the harms the statute was designed to prevent. That aligns with the proposition that violating such a statute constitutes evidence (but not conclusive proof) of negligence.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se…. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.raw_text: Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438 Mass. 317, 322 (2002)
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.proposition: Violation of a safety statute or ordinance designed to protect the public constitutes evidence of negligence.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns vicarious liability and respondeat superior for a physician’s malpractice and does not address negligence per se, safety statutes, or ordinances. Nowhere does the court discuss the evidentiary effect of violating a safety statute or ordinance, nor does it state that such a violation constitutes evidence of negligence. The case therefore does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc., 438.relevant_excerpt: Broadly speaking, respondeat superior is the proposition that an employer, or master, should be held vicariously liable for the torts of its employee, or servant, committed within the scope of employment. ... To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA.

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: A reasonable person in Defendant’s position would foresee that an unleashed, barking, charging dog could cause nearby persons to take evasive action, risking injury even without physical contact.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with proximate cause and governmental immunity in the context of a parole decision and a later shooting; it does not address foreseeability of injuries caused by people reacting to a charging or barking dog. Nothing in the reasoning concerns animals, evasive action to avoid them, or liability without physical contact. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific dog-related foreseeability proposition stated.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct. Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978). In this respect, proximate cause prevents liability from being based on factual causation alone. The definition or scope of proximate cause (or foreseeable result) is in turn “based on considerations of policy and pragmatic judgment.”

Jemison v. Pfeifer, 390 Mass. 168, 170 (.proposition: A reasonable person in Defendant’s position would foresee that an unleashed, barking, charging dog could cause nearby persons to take evasive action, risking injury even without physical contact.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligent conduct.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that negligence and causation are assumed for purposes of the certified questions and expressly notes that those issues are not before the court. The case is about whether Massachusetts allows recovery for negligently inflicted emotional distress without physical harm and related DES issues, not about whether a plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligence. It therefore does not establish or discuss the directness or foreseeability of injury as a result of negligent conduct, and cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress." 386 Mass. at 545.

Delaney v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Delaney v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2005)
Delaney v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligent conduct.
Delaney v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses proximate cause and foreseeability, holding that a jury could find Reynolds’s negligence in leaving a loaded gun accessible to Delaney to be a proximate cause of her self-inflicted injury, even if her act were intentional. The court reverses summary judgment precisely because it cannot be said as a matter of law that her injuries were not a foreseeable result of his alleged negligence. However, the case stops short of definitively finding causation, instead allowing the issue to go to the jury, so it supports the proposition at a general, doctrinal level rather than as a conclusive factual finding.
Delaney v. Reynolds, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: Even were the jury to find that Delaney intended to commit suicide when she turned Reynolds’s gun on herself with an intentional suicidal or self-injurious purpose, we think it should also be open to Delaney to show and the jury to find that the risk that she would handle or use Reynolds’s gun in a manner so as to cause intentional injury to herself was foreseeable and that his failure to secure his gun was a proximate cause of her injury.

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 50–52 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s actions constituted negligence as defined in Restatement (Second) of Torts § 284, adopted by Massachusetts courts.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused on causation and foreseeability, not on defining negligence under Restatement (Second) of Torts § 284 or adopting that Restatement section. The quoted portion does not reference § 284 or articulate a Restatement-based definition of negligence; instead, it applies existing Massachusetts proximate cause and foreseeability standards. Accordingly, this opinion segment does not provide authority for the proposition that defendant’s actions constituted negligence as defined in Restatement § 284 or that Massachusetts courts have adopted that section.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.proposition: Plaintiff suffered actual damages, including bodily injury, medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering, all proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.support_reasoning: The excerpt deals with sufficiency of evidence and the hidden defect rule in premises liability, not with the nature or proof of the plaintiff’s damages. It does not discuss bodily injury, medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or proximate causation of such damages. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about actual damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence.
Poirier v. Plymouth, 374 Mass. 206, 228.relevant_excerpt: This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award costs, prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and post‑judgment interest;

Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declarat.raw_text: Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights
Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declarat.proposition: Reserve Plaintiff’s right to a trial by jury on all issues so triable under Mass. R. Civ. P. 38 and Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38(b).proposition: Pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 38(b), Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
